bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Robert F. Nelson, August 25, 1927

div1.p: Kean rejects Nelson's article on the grounds of inaccuracies. Kean informs him of the Walter Reed Memorial Association's work and Peabody's efforts to lobby Congress for pension increases for the survivors.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Robert F. Nelson, August 25, 1927
div1.opener:
25 August, 1927.
Mr. R. F. Nelson,
Director of Publicity,
Virginia State Chamber of Commerce,
Grace-American Building,
Richmond, Virginia.
My dear Mr. Nelson:
div1.p:
I wish to thank you for your letter of July 20th containing
the story of Walter Reed by Miss Kosslow and the picture of the little
house where Dr. Walter Reed was born. These should have been acknowledged
sooner but I was away on my vacation when they arrived. Walter Reed
did his work in Havana while attached to the Headquarters of General
Fitzhugh Lee at Quemados de Marianao and as I was General Lee's Chief
Surgeon at that time, I was familiar with his work as it was being done
and intensely interested in it. We were besides warm personal friends.
For these reasons I have been enormously interested in everything which
relates to Reed and his work. I fear, however, that I cannot publish
in The Military Surgeon Miss Kosslow's story because it has too many
inaccuracies to appear in a scientific journal. I will mention two or
three:

On page 3 the paragraph “What Insect? He saw a peculiar
mosquito biting a yellow fever patient”. This is not at all the way
the thing occurred. Miss Kosslow evidently read the official reports
and so should have known that this was the place to mention Dr. Carlos
Finlay who for twenty years had been publishing his theory of the mosqui-
toes conveying yellow fever and had identified the particular mosquito
and pointed it out to Reed as the guilty insect. Our Cuban friends
resent bitterly the ignoring of Finlay in this story.

Further down on the same page Reed, were he alive, would cer-
tainly vehemently object to the mixing up of his classical and perfectly
controlled experiments with those of Gorgas and Guiteras which were not
controlled and were made with another object in view. The latter were
brought to a sudden termination by three fatalities in succession. Reed,
on the contrary, lost none of his experimental cases, the one death being
that of the gifted Lazear who was the experimenter and whose death could
be regarded as a melancholy accident. I also think there is much doubt
about any connection between Reed's experiments and the fact that Dr.
Carroll afterwards developed a myo carditis and many years afterwards
Kissinger became paralized. The last four lines of the article should
also be omitted. I do not think that Reed would lay claim to any of the
accomplishments made in them.

I am returning you the picture as you have requested in
your letter, and I would be glad if you would put me on your mailing
list for any literature which you put out in connection with the Reed
Memorial. You may be interested to know that there is in existence
another Reed Memorial Association, organized just after his death and
of which I happen to be now the President. We raised $25,000 towards
a monument to be erected to him in Washington and have the money in-
vested but have, in accordance with the wishes of many of the donors,
given the interest to Mrs. Walter Reed during her life time in order
to eke out the entirely inadequate pension which is given her by the
United States government. A movement is now on foot, headed by Prof.
James E. Peabody, to ask Congress to increase the pensions of Mrs. Reed,
Mrs. Lazear, Mrs. Carroll and Kissinger. I hope your association
will urge our Virginia representatives in the Senate and House to sup-
port this bill.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN
Colonel, U.S.Army, Retired
Editor. JRK/W
